text: The massive castle is impressive.

Two streams of servants and soldiers, carrying numerous womenвЂ™s articles, pass each other. Among them are chambermaids carrying hand-boxes and tiny cases. They sto TaroвЂ™s wife, Lady Kaede, followed by her maids, stops a procession comes to a standstill.
What is going on? She seems hot-tempered, and knits her brows.  15 16 17 17. From the front of the line an old woman comes over with quick, small steps, and, kneeling, explains.
Lord HidetoraвЂ™s mistresses are moving from the castle keep to the outworks, and they will not get out of the way for my ladyвЂ™s procession.
How rude! I am now the lady of this castle. How dare they block my path! The old woman scurries away.
Hidetora is looking out the window.
HidetoraвЂ™s mistresses stand to one side and kneel as th Lady KaedeвЂ™s procession pass by.
Why are my women kneeling to TaroвЂ™s women? It is outrageous! Ikoma, who has been waiting on him at his side, appears annoyed.
How can you say that? Since you have given possession of the caste to Lord Taro, it is only natural. Hidetora suddenly closes the window. Then, suddenly, we h a singing voice.

(Singing) He gives away his house. He gives away his fields... Hidetora looks away.  18. From the corner of the room Kyoami comes out singing and dancing in the same strange costume he previously wore.
(Singing) Our village chief is good-natured. He will end up a scarecrow in the paddy.
(Turns angrily) Are you trying to call me a fool?

God forbid! The fool is me... (Points to himself) ...-here to curry your favor, you illustrious laughingstock... I ama fool. Buy you, my lord... (Points to Hidetora) +..are another. You have lost all you have gained! He dashes away, gesturing like an idiot.
Taro and Lady Kaede, his wife.
How truly auspicious it is that you have ascended to the headship of the House of Ichimonji.

(His whole face smiling) Kaede... (Stands up, looks out window) How many times have I looked out form here on the landscape? And... now that it is mine, this landscape looks entirely different. Kaede, ignoring TaroвЂ™s deep emotion, looks at the upper platform. There are no furnishings on it; it looks bare.
I am sure the standard was displayed there.  19.
(Nods ) FatherвЂ™s standard and his armor and helmet were displayed there.
Well, where are they?
(Casually) I just handed them to Father's bearers. Kaede tightly knits her brows.
I do not care about the armor, but the standard... My lord. That standard is supposed to be with the head of the Hoes of Ichimonji. TaroвЂ™s face reveals a slightly troubled expression.
But Father said that he would keep the title and forms of lordship...
Without the forms you are just a shadow.
What do you mean? Father definitely said that the headship would go to me.
Then behave like it. She rises and shouts down from the top of the staircase.
Somebody! Bring the standard here. Bring the standard back here. It is our lordвЂ™s order.
Yes, my lady! The voice is followed by hasty footsteps. Taro stands in blank amazement.  19 20. Kaede, seeing him from the corner of her eye, crosses to window and gazes out, calm and composed.

A group of people, packed in the narrow passage between t castle battlement and the stone wall, jostle each other i unusual excitement. Swaying in the waves of men is the la Ichimonji standard. HidetoraвЂ™s and TaroвЂ™s retainers are struggling for th banner displaying a golden character that means вЂњone.вЂ
What do you think you are doing?
Take it back to the keep!
The Ichimonji standard belongs to the Great Lord!
It is the head of the houseвЂ™s standard, and Lord Taro is the head of the Ichimonji House now!
Do not let them have it! Do not let them have it!

Give it to us! With a great shout, they whirl about and struggle furious sending up dust. The whirl of dust surrounds the golden character on the banner. Kyoami, who has been watching from a nearby tower, dances singing in a loud voice.
(Sings) That lord is a gourd in the wind, Tottering this way, tottering that... One of TaroвЂ™s retainers looks up at him and runs up the tower.
(Continues) Tottering this way, tottering that. (MORE)
A gourd we will hang from the keep. Wouldn't that be amusing? Reaching the top of the tower, TaroвЂ™s retainer grabs Ky by the collar.

You insolent bastard! I will give you this! He tries to push Kyoami off the tower. At that moment, an arrow, its feathers whistling, flies i the retainerвЂ™s chest. He groans and falls down the ston wall. Shocked, Kyoami falls back and lands on his buttock HidetoraвЂ™s retainers and TaroвЂ™s are startled for an i then look around to see where the arrow came from.
Hidetora standing on the upper story, his foot on the windowsill, one of his sleeves rolled up, holding a bow i his other hand. He has the fierce bearing of a ferocious warrior.
TaroвЂ™s retainers, frightened, run away. Behind them rem the corpse, fallen from the tower, its neck broken.

The Ichimonji standard hangs at the entrance to the castl outworks. In the square beneath the stone steps, bonfires quickly lighted. Hidetora and his attendants and retainer are holding a banquet. The retainers are singing in choru with Kyoami, who dances as he sings.
(Singing) That lord is a gourd in the wind... Hidetora is drinking, watching them sing. Suddenly we hea loud voice.
Who is there? Kyoami shrinks behind Hidetora. TaroвЂ™s attendant, Ogura, is being questioned by a guard  22.
I am a messenger from the keep.
Pass.
Ogura goes into the square and kneels before Hidetora.
I beg to speak. Lord Taro Takatora is holding a family gathering to drink in celebration of the transference of the headship of the house. Therefore, he requests the presence of his father.
Humph! It seems he is summoning me. Hidetora angrily gets to his feet.
Lord Ikoma, you are invited, too.
The donjon seems to float above the bonfires. Lights flic in the windows.

Taro and Kaede are sitting side by side, illuminated by candlelight, their backs to the alcove. That means they a superior to any other in the room. Before them are sakГ© dishes of food, and at a distance, a round straw mat, whi is a lower seat. Hidetora rises from the stairs and looks around.
I heard this was a family celebration. But is it just us?
Yes. Ikoma and Ogura come up and sit side by side behind Hidet  The comic retainers. 23.
Please have a seat.
Am I to take the lower seat? Who do you think I am?
You are my husbandвЂ™s honorable father.
Is that all? What happened to the Great Lord? Is he dead?
Please do not joke.
I am not joking. As I remember, I said I would keep the title and forms of the Great Lord. You must not forget it.
We have not forgotten it. It is you, Father, who have forgotten that you gave the headship of the house to me.
What do you mean? I handed you this castle keep, moved down to the outworks, and even set a limit on the number of my retainers.
They may be few in number, but their actions are intolerable. What does that song mean? song is heard again, sung by HidetoraвЂ™s drunken
(Singing) The gourd in the wind Tottering this way, tottering that. Let us hang this gourd From the castle keep. Wouldn't that be amusing? Then a burst of jeering voices.  24.
Father, with this going on, how can I exercise authority over my men?
They are rough warriors. They do not understand etiquette and politeness. Sometimes they sing comic songs.

Even with comic songs there are limits. It was not unreasonable that one of my retainers rebuked the idiot whose song was clearly making fun of me. But of all things, you shot that retainer of mine. That I cannot overlook. No, I can close my eyes to what happened today, but I want you to pledge firmly that such a thing will never happen again. He looks at Kaede. She takes the thick ceremonial paper t has been placed on the wooden stand table beneath the scr of Hachiman, the god of war, in the alcove, and hands it Hidetora.

I would like you to sign this and seal it with your blood. Hidetora roughly opens the ceremonial paper. When he has glanced over it, he turns to glare, full of menace, at Ta then throws it in from of Ikoma.
This is so absurd that I do not know what to say. Read it. Ikoma picks up the paper and reads it.
(Reading)
Clause 1. I transfer to Taro Takatora the headship of the House of Ichimonji. Clause 2. Therefore, Taro Takatora is now the head of the House of Ichimonji. (MORE)

Clause 3. Hereafter, I, though the father of Taro Takatora, shall submit myself to his authority and shall not act contrary to it. I shall not be guilty of deceit with respect to any of the above clauses. I pledge the above upon any and every god on this land.
Well, do you think I can affix my signature to such a stupid document and seal it in blood?

You were the one who originally suggested this in the presence of the lords Fujimaki and Ayabe. Why does this document bother you now? Ogura immediately puts before Hidetora an inkstone and a brush. It seems that all has been meticulously planned an prepared in advance. Hidetora is instantly cornered. After a momentвЂ™s hesita he indignantly signs the pledge and seals it with his blo He throws the paper at Taro.
Are you my son?
What are you saying?

Is this a childвЂ™s attitude toward his parent? (Glares at Kaede, who is silent and expressionless) The hen makes the rooster cry. He springs to his feet, kicking over the bottles of sakГ© food that have been prepared.
I will not stay in this castle. I have another son. He runs down the stairs, stamping loudly. Ikoma rises to follow him.
(To Ikoma) Well done. Thank you.  25-26 27 26. Ikoma bows and exits. Taro watches him go. His pale face exudes a sense of guilt, a feeling that has yet to be stilled.
(Still seated) How I have longed for this day! Taro looks at his wife, surprised.

I was born and bred in this castle, which used to belong to my father. Then I left it to marry you. My father and brothers, all unaware because of our marriage, were murdered by your father, Hidetora. Then I was brought back to this castle, which was seized from my family... I have waited for this day ever since. Taro looks at Kaede, horrified. She is quiet for a while, then slowly looks around the room.
This is the room where my mother committed suicide. Her glance frozen, her eyes shining strangely, she is qui still. Madness rises from her beautiful immobility. Taro stares at her.
Although the Second Castle is smaller in scale than the First, its black structure gives a feeling of warlike ferocity.  28 27.

Thick pillars and crossbeams run vertically and horizonta crisscrossing, making the interior dim, though outside it still daytime. The weapons lined against the wooden wall a sense of warlike brutality. Surrounding Jiro, who is reading a letter, are his three confidants: Kurogane, Shirane, and Naganuma.
My father is on his way here. He was politely thrown out of the First Castle. The three confidants exchange glances.

My brother's letter says that it is dangerous to let our selfish father in the castle. That is not all. It also says that Ikoma, his aide, understands my brotherвЂ™s intentions. He hands the letter to Kurogane, who peruses it.
Hmm... Lord TaroвЂ™s unusual severity is almost unbelievable. By the way, my lord, why are you sitting there quietly doing nothing?
Exactly. You are the one who should be following in the footsteps of the Great Lord and assuming the burden of ruling this land. Lord Taro does not have that ability.
If I were you, I should stake my whole life on this chance. Kurogane and Naganuma nod slowly. A faint smile comes to Jiro's lips as he watches the three. His face in uncannil gentle, like a woman's.
Then all of you are willing to stake your lives with mine?
Just as you say.  28.
The hunting dogs will not follow their master if he lets the game go.
If you are not fleet, then you are our game.
How the dogs howl! Lord and vassals exchange words without restraint, as tho equals; in their manner can be felt the bonds that tightl link them. The three
It has always bothered me as well. Why should I have to spend my life groveling at my elder brotherвЂ™s feet just because I was born twelve months later? I will kick off these shackles.
Right, my lord. Splendid...
Save your breath! Listen carefully. My brother is no problem. But his wife, Lady Kaede, is.
That is true. She should be perfect for you. Why not steal her from him?

Do not be so direct. But before that there is also my father. He may have retired, but he took thirty retainers with him - every one of them a brave warrior... a match for a thousand. He will soon come here with those brave warriors. What shall we do? aides shout almost unanimously.
It is not wise to let him in.  29 30 31 29.
Hidetora rides onto the huge gate, Ikoma and the other retainers as well as concubines and women attendants following.
It is Hidetora. Let us pass! His loud voice is overwhelming, not belying his magnifice look. A guard peeks out a loophole, then hastily retracts head. The castle gate opens.

On the outside is a small gate, on the inside a large one The large gate is called the front gate, and the small ga facing the outside is called the castle gate. Though smal than the front gate, the castle gate is not really small. The guards prostrate themselves. Hidetora rides in. Ikoma beside him, followed by his retainers and servants, all d with dust and sweat, as well as his fatigued concubines a attendants. Their state of exhaustion tells of their miserable travel across the field in the blazing summer s The great doors of the front gate open for Hidetora. He r in, passing by the kneeling guards.
(To chief guard) The women are tired. Let them rest in the shade and give them water. (Pause) I will see SuГ© first. (Pause) Tell Jiro that I will see him later. (Turns to passage)
A tiny cottage standing in solitude within the grandiose castle grounds. Hidetora comes and calls inside the cotta
There is no answer. Hidetora opens the door to the cottag There is no one inside. One the little altar, a portrait the Amitabha. Inside the dim room, it is a shining golden figure.  32 33 30.

A stone wall soaring in the lingering light, describing a arc like the gradient of a Japanese fan. Above it, the fi of a woman standing in a long robe of wadded silk, and kneeling behind her the tiny figures of an old woman and chambermaid.
Lady SuГ©, her hands together holding a rosary, is prayin the western sky, where the setting sun is giving off its shafts of light.
Hail the Western Paradise, to the Amitabha in thirty-six trillion identical manifestations.
Oh, just as I thought, you are here. (Approaches ) The old woman and the chambermaid, seeing Hidetora, prost themselves as though frightened.
(Regards Hidetora) Father-in-law... She is about to prostrate herself, but Hidetora takes her hand.

No ceremony. It has been a long time. Let me see your face. (Looks at her tenderly as if at his own child) You always have a sad face... Every time I see you it pains me. She tries to smile. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) That is even more heartbreaking. He turns his eyes away, but then looks sharply at her, fi takes her by the shoulders, and shakes her.
It was I, Hidetora, who burned your castle with your father and mother and your family in it. (MORE)

Why do you look at me like that? Rather glare at me with hatred. It would make me feel easier. But she continues gazing gently at Hidetora. He lets his hands drop weakly from her shoulders. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) Circumstances forced me to burn that castle... If your father had just opened the castle to me and had lowered his head to me, I would not have burned it, and your father and mother would not have died... No, there is no use in talking about it now. Go on, hate me!
I do not hate you. Everything has been preordained in our previous lives... All things are the heart of the Buddha...

The Buddha again? There are no Buddhas in todayвЂ™s wold. This is a degraded age, when the BuddhaвЂ™s guardians, Bonten and Taishaku, have been routed by raging Asuras. It is not a world where we can rely on the BuddhaвЂ™s compassion. SuГ© looks up sadly at Hidetora. He looks down on her wit pity. Jiro and Naganuma come running up the stone steps. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) (Seeing them) Is that you, Jiro? Son, I am going to be a guest in your castle. Jiro... I am disappointed in Taro. I can no longer consider him my child. You, too, are not to think of him as your brother. Listen to what happened...
(Interrupting) Father, I already know what happened from my brotherвЂ™s letter.
You received a letter from Taro?  34 32.
According to his letter, your retainers were rough and wild beyond toleration. He wrote that I should greet you with a sonвЂ™s proper courtesy, but not to let your retainers into my castle.
What? You think I am going to come into the castle all alone, leaving my followers to rot outside?
Lord Taro is the head of the House of Ichimonji, and I have no choice but to obey his instructions. Hidetora is shocked, speechless, his body shaking with violent rage.
If you think that is unreasonable, it might be best for you to go apologize to my elder brother and go back to the First Castle.

Apologize to Taro and go back to the First Castle? He forgets his dignity and lets out a sorrowful cry. SuГ© stands there watching the two of them with tears in eyes. Is it the golden western sky illuminating her figur that gives her the very appearance of a weeping Buddha? Then we hear a burst of unusual sounds and shouts.
The garrison are driving HidetoraвЂ™s retainers out of th gate, levelling their spears.

What are you doing? You did not give us water, and now you do this to us? Outrageous! If the Great Lord hears about this, you will be severely punished! Outside the gate is a group of concubines and women tremb in fear, gazing at the unbelievable happening.  35 36 33. Kyoami is sitting alone, apart from the women, a hand on cheek, observing calmly. Standing behind the retainers, Ikoma shouts.
Lord Kurogane! Lord Shirane! Just what is this treatment? Kurogane and Shirane ignore him, sneering, standing behin the garrison.
Hidetora, Jiro, and Naganuma come running.

The garrison push HidetoraвЂ™s retainers brutally out of gate and close the doors. But the doors begins to open ag banged and pushed hard by the retainers outside. The guar push them back and bar the doors. Kurogane steps forward calls out.

Lord Ikoma! Lord Ikoma! An order from the Great Lord! Hidetora, who has come running with Jiro and Naganuma, st to listen. KUROGANE (CONTвЂ™D) вЂњToday we have come so suddenly that the castle has to make preparation for us. Wait quietly outside until is it ready.вЂќ These are the Great LordвЂ™s instructions. Hidetora looks sharply at Jiro. Jiro prepares for his fatherвЂ™s furious reproach. But contrary to his anticipa Hidetora is calmly gazing at Jiro with profound sadness i his eyes. Jiro looks down to avoid his gaze.
This is enough. I understand. (Calmly, as if groaning) You are not in the least different from Taro. You, too, want to get rid of me.  37 34.
Not at all. I would have been delighted to welcome you if you had come alone.
Humph! You know that I could not do that.
Father, if you are retired and intend to depend on your sons, there should be no need for retainers.

Only the birds and the beasts can live by themselves. No more excuses! He straightens himself and shouts. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) Open the gate! The soldiers are immobile, gazing aghast at the old lord. Hidetora gives a sharp surveying look over them. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) Why do you hesitate? I said to open the gate, not for my retainers to enter, but for me to exit. Open the gate! Overwhelmed by his strong voice, the soldiers hurriedly o the gate. Hidetora strides through the gate, stops, and l back fiercely at Jiro. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) Close the doors! I shall not see you again! Jiro is immobile, scared. Kurogane urges the guards to cl the doors.

Hidetora stands in front of the closed front gate, his bo full of fury and strength like an angry god of war. He lo around; his retainers and women are worriedly gazing at h Suddenly he bursts into a hysterical laugh; then, as if enervated, he staggers. Kyoami hurriedly runs up to hold  38 35.

A hot, calm summer day. There seems to be no living thing the field in the sun. The Ichimonji standard hangs loosel without a breeze. HidetoraвЂ™s concubines are lying in the shade of a few t covering their faces with the sleeves of their beautiful garments. The retainers are sleeping like logs, half nake Hidetora, still in possession of the air of a great lord, seated on a stool, gazing into space, face contorted painfully. Ikoma, seated behind him, looks up at him searchingly. Some retainers gallop in. They dismount and kowtow to Hidetora.
There is no one in the village.

Except for this deserted old man... One of the retainers pulls down a gaunt old farmer who ha been clinging to the horse. The old man collapses to the ground, timidly looking at Hidetora, trembling in fear.
No rice bales in the granaries; not a grain of rice in the houses.

The farmers must have fled to the mountains with the rice to avoid us. Hidetora seems to be listening to their report but is obviously preoccupied with other thoughts. He nods absent not realizing what is happening. The retainers withdraw, disappointed, dragging the old man away.
My lord... we have no other way than to go to the Third Castle. It was there you first raised your flag. Go there and once again...
(Stares at Ikoma, interrupting) Idiot! (MORE)

If I could do that, I would not have stayed hungry and tired like this, wandering aimlessly like a beast. Just think. Will the Third Castle garrison welcome the one who banished their master? Ikoma does not answer. Kyoami, crouching beside Hidetora, regards Ikoma and shrugs his shoulders. Hidetora returns gaze into space.

This is a mountain caste. It rises resolutely in front of rigid mountain, at the top of a steep slope. It is even smaller than the Second Castle, but the marks of recent repair and enlargement are still new. With white tiers ad onto the old wooden frame, the castle looks like the awe- inspiring figure of a young Samurai wearing white armor.
Ogura, stately in noble headgear and courtly robes, comes riding up, leading TaroвЂ™s retainers, and shouts into th castle.
By the order of Lord Taro Takatora, head of the House of Ichimonji, I, Ogura, have come to take possession of this castle. Open the gate! A dead silence within the castle.

Although we fully understand the wholehearted devotion of the garrison whose master, Saburo Naotora, has become an exile, open the gate and let us in in peace. Then you will be accepted as Lord TaroвЂ™s retainers with your present positions and allowances. There is no answer from inside the castle.

Open the gate! Open the gate!  54 55 37. The great doors slowly open to the left and right, reveal a crowd of Samurai in the castle square, either on horseb or on foot, in their armor and helmets, spears and bows i hand. Ogura and TaroвЂ™s retainers gasp in surprise, then hurri prepare for combat. But the soldiers inside the castle me form ranks. The mounted men in front spur their horses to a trot and out quietly. The bearded Samurai, Hatakeyama, is in the l

(To Ogura) Without Master Saburo this castle means nothing to us. We are in accord. Our only way is to follow Master Saburo and die for him. We hear he is in the Fujimaki domains. We are proceeding there. Out of our way, if you please! The soldiers of the Third Castle imposingly depart in formation, glaring contemptuously at Ogura and TaroвЂ™s retainers as they go.
Tango, disguised as a hunter, comes leading a horse. The retainers rise from the grass. Their grazing horses neigh lifting their heads.
Lord Hirayama! They sit formally with respect. Tango lets the retainers care of his horse, which is carrying a load of food.

Rice. Bean paste and pickled plums, too. (Sits, bows to Hidetora, who is a short distance away ) I, Tango Hirayama, have followed you in this guise, observing what was happening to you, my lord. You have suffered so much that I could no longer remain in the shadows. (MORE)
Although I have been banished, I would be pleased if you would accept my service.

(Reacts, stands up) Oh, it is you, Tango! Ikoma casts a scheming glance at Hidetora, then calls to retainers, who are cheerfully unloading the horse Tango h brought. The gift quickly changes their gloomy mood.
Wait! We cannot accept food without good reason. Even if it means starving, Samurai cannot accept charity from farmers. Hearing this, HidetoraвЂ™s rage is rekindled.
Exactly! The farmers should not have done this! Burn the villages! All of them! Tango rushes to Hidetora.
My lord! Wait! The farmers are not to blame. They could not ignore Lord TaroвЂ™s orders, so they evacuated their villages to avoid you.
What did that damned Taro say?

He issued a proclamation that the Great Lord was banished and that anyone who helped him would be punished with death. Shocked, Hidetora gapes and collapses to the stool. The retainers and concubines are speechless as they gaze at t once-powerful lord. Summer cicadas chirp in the otherwise quiet field. After what seems an eternity to Tango, Hidet turns to him.
Only now have your admonitions been brought to me.  39.
Thank you, my lord.
Laugh, Tango! Look what has become of Hidetora! The poor old man, betrayed by his children, thrown out of his two castles, has no place to go!
My lord! You do have a place to go! Master Saburo has found a place with Lord Fujimaki, who wishes him to be his son-in-law. You should go to him.
How should I? You tell me, with what kind of face can I go to Saburo?

(Even more strongly) Great Lord! Listen carefully. Master Saburo thinks of nothing but his fatherвЂ™s welfare. It is because of him that I have disguised myself like this so that I could be by your side. It is all because of his orders that I protect you. These words have a deeply moving effect on Hidetora. His twists in spite of himself. Torn between joy and shame, t stern face of a great general disappears, giving way to t face of a frail old father. One of HidetoraвЂ™s retainers gallops up.
I beg to speak. All the soldiers of the Third Castle have surrendered the castle to Lord Ogura. They formed ranks and left for the Fujimaki domains.
What!
Now you see what FujimakiвЂ™s intentions are. (MORE)

First he takes Saburo as a son-in- law, then he takes his soldiers, and then he will take you, my lord, so that the House of Ichimonji will split and fight each other. He will be able to capture this land without soiling his hands.
What are you saying? Lord Fujimaki is not a man like that.
(Ignores Tango) My lord, let us go to the Third Castle immediately! Hidetora springs to his feet.
My lord! He grabs HidetoraвЂ™s sleeve.
(Pushes his hand away) Do not tell me what to do in this emergency, you exile! Men! First, we go into the Third Castle!
The Third Castle has been occupied by Lord Ogura and his troop.
It does not matter. Ogura will understand. Kyoami, who has been crouching, suddenly looks up and sni
It stinks. It is the smell of rotten guts. Ikoma looks back at him sharply. Kyoami shrugs his should and crouches again. Hidetora watches them, perplexed.
My lord. OguraвЂ™s troops are powerless. We can beat them if necessary. Tango begins to speak but is interrupted.  56 57 58 59 41.
Get my horse! A retainer comes running with a horse. Hidetora hastily mounts it. Tango has no chance to speak.
Go quickly. Heaven is far away, but Hell is not. Hidetora turns sharply to Kyoami. The next moment, with a fierce glare, he strikes Kyoami in the face with his whip

You cur! Do not come if you are afraid! Die! During all this, while Hidetora, Tango, and Ikoma argue, retainers and ladies-in-waiting are so shocked by the sud turn of events that they stand there gaping.

The same scene as before, but gloomy now, with clouds han over it. Also, the summer grass, crushed and broken under feet of HidetoraвЂ™s men, gives the feeling that one is l at the traces of manвЂ™s evildoing, the mood of a pestile On it are two unmoving shadows - those of Tango and Kyoam fresh welt on his face, tears running down over it. Tango looks dolefully at Kyoami.
We were sincere and spoke the truth. Kyoami, sobbing, turns up his face like a crying child.
Hidetora and his party are entering the castle. Ikoma and Ogura are on their knees waiting beside the gate. After t party passes, the great doors close, squeaking ominously.
Hidetora, who has been in his bed with his concubine slee beside him, sits up when he hears hasty footsteps and shouting voices.  60 61 62 63 64 42.
Great Lord! Great Lord! An emergency!
What is it?
A large army has surrounded the castle!
(Leaps up) What! Is it Fujimaki?

No, it is Lord Taro at the front and Lord Jiro at the rear. Hidetora stares in blank amazement for a moment, then run out of the room with a speed that belies his age. The hal naked woman left on the bed looks shamefully unkempt.
The Ichimonji standard and HidetoraвЂ™s armor are display a corner. Hidetora hurriedly comes up the stairs, runs to the windo one side, opens it, and looks out.
Soldiers clamoring outside the castle; flashes of fire sp from the gun muzzles of the riflers in the front row. The the resounding roar of rifle shots.
Hidetora bites his lip and strains to see.
Amid the smoke streaming from the rifles, Taro can be see horseback directing the soldiers.  65 66 67 68 69 43.
Hidetora fiercely shakes his head as if it were a nightma looks down again, then, turning around in terrified amazement, opens the window on the other side and looks d
Here, too, soldiers are clamoring. With the shooting atta of the riflers, the spear brigade rushes for the gate, at head of the ranks, mounted, is Jiro.
Hidetora, swaying, pulls back and calls down the stairs.
Is someone there? Call Ikoma! Where is Ogura? Below the stairs, a retainer, hurriedly putting on his ar appears.

Both have abandoned the castle and run to the enemy position! Great Lord! This is the end! Hidetora, his strength drained from his body, slips and tumbles down the stairs like a dead man falling into Hell A terrible scroll of Hell is shown depicting the fall of castle. There are no real sounds as the scroll unfolds li daytime nightmare. It is a scene of human evildoing, the of the demonic Asura, as seen by a Buddha in tears. The music superimposed on these pictures is, like the BuddhaвЂ™s heart, measured in beats of profound anguish, chanting of a melody full of sorrow that begins like sobb and rises gradually as it is repeated, like karmic cycles then finally sounds like the wailing of countless Buddhas
A retainer hurled into the air by an explosion is thrown and dies.  70 71 72 73 74 75 76 77 78
Black smoke sweeping the ground; a cloud of dust. A retai his hair still disheveled from sleep, screams something a staggers left and right with a weird slowness like someon running in a dream.
Horses run madly out of the stables that have fallen in t explosion.
Women in pandemonium - a whirl of voluptuous colors: red, blue, yellow, violet, and pink.
The sun appears from between the low-hanging clouds. Blac smoke blocks the abnormal color and light of the sun.

head_text.subj: TONGUES OF RED FLAME AMID THE BLACK SMOKE
A SNAKE CRAWLING OUT OF A HOLE IN THE STONE WALL

text: Retainers open the great doors on orders from Ogura - all have the appearances of screaming demons. The spear-carriersвЂ™ brigade and the riflersвЂ™ brigade the castle like an avalanche. The corpses of HidetoraвЂ™s retainers are trampled underfoot by them, spurting out bl The glitter of spears and swords; black smoke and dust en the swaying flagpole.

Ikoma is standing with the great gate opened behind him. has a demonвЂ™s expression as he screams something. The m the riflersвЂ™ brigade that has pushed its way in kneel a begin to shoot. Fire and smoke. A forest of spears and bo thrusts ahead through the smoke.

head_text.subj: A RAIN OF ARROWS FLYING THROUGH THE BLACK SMOKE

text: A stream of retainers are running away. Hidetora appears among them, shouting commands in a crazed voice. A man screams as he crawls away to escape, an arrow piercing hi leg.
Black smoke curls around saddles and stirrups of gold lacquerwork, leopardskin saddlecloths, and other colorful horse ornaments.
Bullets spray dust around the battlement.
Sparks of fire in the black smoke, flaming scraps of bann flying about. The crest on the banner - a butterfly with wings open - looks as if it were writhing.

head_text.subj: A BLOOD-SMEARED RETAINER, SURROUNDED AND STABBED BY SPEAR

text: Cornered and stabbed, a retainer falls. ARCHERSвЂ™ BRIGADE SHOOTING ARROWS IN A VOLLEY

head_text.subj: A MAN PIERCED WITH ARROWS LIKE A PORCUPINE

text: The cavalry charges. Poles with fluttering bannerets of various colors. Plumes on glittering helmets, the faces underneath like those of evil demons.  89 90 91 92 93 94 95 96 97 98 46.
The attacking cavalry. Corpses trampled under their horse hooves. A man running away is bent back, skewered.
Among the cavalry racing up the way, a man is running abo trying to escape, holding his own severed arm.

A man comes running, his whole body splashed with blood a his hair undone and hanging down. He clings to a pillar, slithers down to the ground. Smeared on the pillar is a bloody handprint and a streak of blood.
A stream of blood with islands of severed arms and hands.

head_text.subj: THE EYE WITH AN ARROW STAGGERS WITH THE ARR
STILL STUCK IN HIS BLOOD-SMEARED FACE

text: Foot soldiers fighting over the colorful, voluptuous wome clothes and womenвЂ™s articles. Black smoke creeps in.
Enemy men raping chambermaids. A half-naked chambermaid p up a fallen sword, stabs herself in the chest, and sudden falls. The rice bales are covered with blood.

The wooden door opens, and Hidetora, bathed in a spray of blood and holding a bloody sword, peers out. The two concubines face each other and stab daggers into each oth hearts. Being who they are, they are not disheveled;  99 100 101 102 103 104 47. they wear light makeup, have their robes tied at the knee for decencyвЂ™s sake, and are beautifully attired in long dresses. Something in the beautiful way they die touches heart. Hidetora watches the scene, standing as if petrified.
Women in waiting who have run away jump off, with daggers their mouths - the sleeves of their voluptuous robes trai they plunge headfirst.
Here, too, the smoke creeps in. Amid the smoke, the Ichim standard and HidetoraвЂ™s helmet are displayed in a corne Hidetora runs up the stairs. He goes round and round in t room like a madman.
To this floor Shirane and Naganuma come looking for Hidet They are forced by the onslaught of arrows to crouch on t stairs.
Taro comes riding up, greeted by his retainers in a frenz over their victory. He wears armor with pale green braids a helmet with a plume. This also is the figure of a young general.
Jiro and his army march in. With his grass-green armor an helmet, he has the air of a great warrior.
Taro, mounted, comes with his men up the slope, now piled high with corpses, where the blood runs like a river. He composed. Then - a gunshot.

105 106 48. From this point, the track bursts into real sounds: the shouts of soldiers running around, footsteps, hoofbeats, fluttering of banners and bannerets, the roar of fire. In the midst of these sounds, Taro clutches at his throat with one hand, blood pouring out between his fingers. He reels around and falls heavily from his horse.
Hidetora runs up the stairs. Obviously he has fought hard throws away his broken sword, sits down with a thud, and glares into space, his face full of chagrin and fury.

The top story is defended impregnably. Shirane and Naganu as well as the Samurai who have come rushing up behind th are showered by the onslaught of arrows coming from the battlements on their left and right. Two of the Samurai w have rushed up the stairs receive arrows in the chest and forearm, and fall back on Shirane and Naganuma.
Jiro, who has been sitting on a stool, stands up
What? My elder brother has been killed?
He was shot by a soldier lying in ambush with a rifle near the watchtower on the outworks.
Oh...

Do not grieve, my lord. Kurogane comes out of the smoke. Jiro starts as he sees KuroganeвЂ™s cold expression; he casts a hurried glance a rifle Kurogane is holding. KUROGANE (CONTвЂ™D) Such is a warriorвЂ™s fortune... yours is better than Master TaroвЂ™s! You are hereby Lord Jiro Masatora, head of the House of Ichimonji.
Jiro falls into a daze, then regains his senses.
What has happened to my father?
He has holed up in the donjon with the few remaining enemy soldiers.
I suppose he will commit harakiri. He casually tosses aside the rifle he has been holding.
Hidetora, who has been gazing into space, bares his stoma preparing for harakiri and reaches at his waistband for h dagger - but it is gone. Startled, he hastily looks aroun

Naganuma, Shirane, and other are forced by the onslaught arrows to crouch on the stairs. Smoke is already rising h too; smoke blown up from below is sucked into the donjon stairwell. We hear a scream:
This is the end! The iron battlement doors open on the right and left, and four retainers come tumbling out.
My lord, farewell! Goodbye, my lord! They stab each other.

Hidetora is looking for his dagger as desperately as a hu animal. An honorable death by harakiri means a lot to him Should he e defeated by a nameless soldier, the shame wou be intolerable.  108 109 110 111 112 113 114 50.

Jiro, Kurogane, and their men run over. Smoke pours from donjon windows above, and tongues of flame lick at the wo walls of the lower stories. From the entrance emerge Naganuma, Shirane, and several Samurai who are running aw Jiro stops, looks away. From the donjon entrance comes Hidetora, trailing smoke, which wraps around him. His white hair is bristling, and is staggering as if treading on air, staring vacantly int space. Jiro and all the others pull back from the mad Hidetora t let him pass.
The moat is filled with layers of bodies, some still movi
The mad Hidetora goes staggering down the slope. Samurai foot soldiers slide away to open up his path but cannot a their eyes from him.
Black, burned bodies are smoldering.
The madman Hidetora walks. Enemy soldiers scramble away a hug the stone walls, letting him pass.
The moat is filled with corpses instead of water.

The mad Hidetora comes out staggering. Soldiers make way him, watching him. The ranks break, and Jiro appears. Following Jiro are Kurogane, Shirane, Naganuma, Ikoma, and Ogura.  115 116 117 118 119 51. Jiro gazes at Hidetora from behind, then spontaneously ru after him.

My lord! Jiro stops as if nailed to the ground and stands there watching his father walk away. KUROGANE (CONTвЂ™D) The die is cast. Do not hesitate. This road you are taking is a way of no return. Once you step out on it, against your conscience, you must keep going straight without hesitation. The road will lead to the headship of the House of Ichimonji. You have no choice.
It spews fire.
HidetoraвЂ™s armor and helmet and the Ichimonji standard the hellfire.
Tango comes racing up on his horse. Sitting in back of hi clinging to Tango, is Kyoami. The horse is running toward black smoke belching from a valley in the far foothills. blast of wind.
Black clouds descend like swooping dragons. Then they bre into a thousand shreds that race and fly. Rain and lightn strike the earth.
Tango racing his horse through the typhoon winds, thunder and rain. Kyoami is clinging to his waist.  120 52.
The very wilderness of insanity. A small shadow wandering the mad gales, in the downpour, among the thunderclaps an the lightning bolts. Tango, who has raced over on horseback, looks at the shad
Who is that? Kyoami strains his eyes and looks, then moves up and down the horse in a frenzy.
Am I dreaming? Oh, Heaven forbid!

The Great Lord! He turns his horseвЂ™s head, racing after Hidetora at ful gallop. HidetoraвЂ™s white hair and beard, disheveled in the wind drenched by the rain, are stuck to his face. His flutteri garments are likewise wrapped around his body. He stands sharply like a demon god, scowling all around him. Tango and Kyoami, who have galloped up and jumped off the horse in front of him, are rooted to the ground with frig at his extraordinary appearance. Hidetora screams at the raging plain.
I am a messenger from Heaven! This is HeavenвЂ™s war! Smash the rebels that turn against Heaven! Forward, men, forward! Tango runs up to him.
Great Lord! Have you gone mad?
(Starts dancing) Go mad! Go mad! In this mad world it is the sane who are mad!
Forward! Forward! I am the sun!  53.
The Great Lord is great indeed!
What do you mean?
If you are going to go mad, it is better to think you are the sun than to think you are a worm. Tango is silent.
Forward, men! Have no mercy! This is HeavenвЂ™s punishment! Kyoami is dancing himself into a frenzy.

Bravo! Bravo! Men are beasts! Kill them all and the world will be paradise! Hidetora suddenly becomes quiet and still, gazing intentl some point in the distance. Kyoami puts his hand in front HidetoraвЂ™s eyes and moves it up and down but, failing a point, suddenly straightens.

You have come, you have come out with your hatred for Hidetora! Come on, I will give you a taste of destruction! He is unarmed, but he grabs an invisible sword and takes fighting stance. Seeing this, Kyoami sings a parody of a verse from the No play Funa-benket.

(Sings) How strange! On withered fields I see an entire clan destroyed by my hands, each one of them floating up before me. Hidetora runs madly about, back and forth, left and right waving his fists. Fighting the ghosts of his enemies who appearing in front of him, Hidetora displays an expressio and bearing that are the extreme of madness.  54. Tango is, of course, amazed. But even Kyoami wants to shi his eyes as he watches, unable to move. Hidetora, mad, reaches the limits of his strength and collapses. Tango, after a moment, pulls himself together and runs ov
Great Lord! He shakes Hidetora as if clinging to him.
Great Lord! Come to your senses! Hidetora opens his eyes, and, looking for a moment at Tan who is watching him, he stands.
Is it you, Tango?
(His face lights up) Yes, my lord!
(Looks around) Where am I? It is cold. He is shivering in the violent wind, the rain slanting ac him.
Kyoami, rejoice! Our lord has regained his senses!
That is worse. If he were still mad, he would be spared the memory of what had happened to him. The wind and rain rage violently.

(In a sudden groaning voice) Tango, hear me! I, Hidetora, was attacked by Taro and Jiro! Tango is dumbfounded. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) Ikoma, too, betrayed me.  121 55. Tango is shocked. HIDETORA (CONTвЂ™D) And then I was so easily defeated. Now you may laugh at me, laugh at my stupidity! Because of my stupidity, my retainers are dead! The rain strikes HidetoraвЂ™s face, and the wind lifts hi hair. He shouts. The wind and rain are fiercer than ever.
These are their tears! Their weeping voices!

Autumn has come early to the mountains, and in this valle the autumn flowers mowed down by the storm are scattered about. There is something tragic about the scene, as if a resplendent dress had been discarded. Tango and Kyoami go along the narrow road through the pla with Hidetora on the horse. At the end of the narrow road stands a miserable straw hu looking as if it were embraced by the mountain. Smoke fro the hearth is quietly rising. Hidetora lies on the horseвЂ™s back, his face, eyes stari vacantly, helplessly swaying. Tango stops the horse in front of the straw hut and calls inside the house.
Anybody home? From inside the house, a delicate voice is heard.
Who is it?
Travelers who have met hardship in todayвЂ™s storm. Please let us stay a night.
My house is too poor to put anyone up...  56.
We are not asking for anything special.
Because of personal reasons, I do not want to come in contact with anyone.
Why? Is it a disease?
No.
Then please let us in.
I am sorry. I cannot...
(Irritated) Listen, the Great Lord of the House of Ichimonji is here! There is no answer, and the house becomes completely quie
We are coming in. Then, together with Kyoami, he carries Hidetora off the horse, opens the door, and goes into the straw hut.

A small earthen floor; in the corner of it, a simple washstand. On the other side of the earthen floor, a smal room with a mat laid out. It looks as if it might serve a both sitting room and sleeping room. It is already dark inside the hut. In the center of the wooden floor, sittin the little hearth, a figure with long hair in the style o temple acolytes can be seen in the dim light of the fire.

Excuse us for coming in with our shoes on, but our lord was suddenly taken ill... He steps up on the wooden floor and, together with Kyoami carries Hidetora over to the hearth and, laying him there addresses the occupant of the house, seemingly a woman.  57.
(Looks at the occupant) He is wet. Do you have something to cover him with? The occupant stays seated and does not move.
Answer me, woman!
Are you talking to me?

Yes. The occupant of the house silently rises and goes to a co of the room. Tango and Kyoami watch the person suspicious The occupant, seen from behind in the dim light, appears be looking for something. The occupant rises and comes over, silently handing somet over. Tango receives it - it is folded clothing. He opens puts it on Hidetora, and stares in surprise. It is a beautiful robe with a colorful design, out of keeping wit the humble hut. Tango and Kyoami are amazed and curious a they look at it.
Speak up... woman!
I am not a woman.
What? It is so dark, I... Bring me a lamp. Tango reaches for a stick of lighted firewood in order to take a good look at him, and notices a cane leaning by th side of the hearth.

I am sorry. Is your eyesight poor? He holds up the stick of firewood. The occupant of the ho is illuminated in the light from the burning stick. It is face of a blind but handsome youth. Kyoami pulls back wit start and looks at Tango.  58.
(Shocked, gazes at the youth) Are you Lady SuГ©вЂ™s younger brother... Master Tsurumaru?
Yes. Hidetora sits up, turns his eyes, and stares at the youth Then, his voice trembling, he mutters with a frightened voice.
Tsu... Tsurumaru?
It has been a long time... Lord Hidetora.
Do you remember me?

How could I forget you? I was just a child, but how could I forget the one who gouged out my eyes in exchange for sparing my life... the day you burned down my fatherвЂ™s castle? Hidetora is trembling.

I tried hard to follow my sister's teachings, to pray to the Buddha and rid myself of hatred. But not one day have I failed to remember, and not one night have I been able to forget and to sleep peacefully. Hidetora, naturally, and Tango and Kyoami also stare at t blind boy, speechless.

Well, then, I am terribly sorry that I cannot give you a decent welcome, Great Lord. However... fortunately I have a flute that my sister sent to me. I learned to play it when I was a child. I will play it for you and give you, if nothing else, some hospitality of the heart.  123 124 125 126 59. The boy takes a flute from the brocade bag beside him.

Now it is my only pleasure. Please listen, and laugh, if you will, at my clumsy art. Seated before Hidetora, Tango and Kyoami, Tsurumaru plays The clear sound of the flute expresses TsurumaruвЂ™s deep sorrow and lament. It moves Hidetora. The old lord stagge to his feet. He clutches at his chest like a man shot wit arrow. His face twitching, staring at Tsurumaru with star eyes, he steps back. With trembling lips he tries to say something, but his voice fails him. He opens his mouth wi and lets out a scream that is not a voice, then staggers to the earthen floor, quickly pushes at the door, and tum outside.
My lord! He runs after Hidetora. Kyoami follows.
Hidetora staggers over the field scattered with autumn flowers in the moonlight, as if running from something fearful.
The crescent moon.
Impressive thunderheadlike clouds.
A topknot on a piece of white paper placed on the polishe wooden floor.
My dear sister-in-law, this was the hair of my deceased brother. Lady Kaede is in the seat of honor, with Jiro in front of her. Lined up behind her are the chief retainers in armor  60.
It was my accursed turn of fortune to have to be the one to inform you of the death in battle of my elder brother. Kaede stares piercingly at Jiro.
(To Ogura beside Jiro) Ogura... where are the remains of my lord? Ogura looks at Jiro as if asking for help.

In this sweltering heat... the corpse was so unsightly that we had to refrain from placing it on view. We had no choice but to cremate it at the Third Castle and hold an informal funeral at a nearby temple.
Ogura... where are the armor and helmet he was wearing? Ogura seems to shrink.
That is sarcasm, I think. This armor and this helmet I am wearing now are the ones he was wearing. You have not forgotten, have you?
I have not forgotten. But I never thought you could wear his armor and helmet so soon after his death. It is too much for me to notice.

I am surprised at you. I thought my deceased brother would be happy to know that his younger brother returned to the castle in his armor. No, it was foolish of me. Forgive me. (Bows to her, rises) I am taking off this armor. Somebody, help me.
127 61. An attendant runs over and starts taking off his armor. TaroвЂ™s retainers become intently still at this.
Sister-in-law... I am about to be naked. Kaede quietly rises and goes out.
Impressive clouds soaring.
Jiro is seated in the masterвЂ™s seat, his back to the al Kurogane, Shirane, and Naganuma are beside him. Ikoma and Ogura, dressed in casual attire, are seated facing Jiro.

(to Ikoma and Ogura) You have worked hard for us on this occasion of the Ichimonji family trouble. We appreciate it. Ikoma and Ogura bow. KUROGANE (CONTвЂ™D) As a token of our thanks, we have prepared a humble gift for you. Two low wooden stands, each with a pile of gold coins, ar placed in front of Ikoma and Ogura. KUROGANE (CONTвЂ™D) Please accept it. Ikoma and Ogura bow deeply to Jiro.
(Nods ) It is my farewell gift for you. (Pause) Goodbye. Ikoma and Ogura look at him in amazement.
Lord Jiro is now the head of the House of Ichimonji. (MORE)

Considering his situation and what you did to your master this time, he thinks it is not very wise to keep you, who committed treason, on his staff. It would be dangerous. His concern is understandable. We have nothing further to say. (Pause) Let there be no hard feelings. Ikoma and Ogura look at each other and start to say something. KUROGANE (CONTвЂ™D) (Interrupting) Do you understand? Good. Thank you. Ikoma and Ogura are helpless.
(From downstairs) I beg to speak. Lady Kaede is entering. Kurogane looks at Jiro, his eyes implying вЂњWatch out!вЂ nods readily.

(Calling downstairs) Send her in. (To Jiro) Let us withdraw. (Rises) Shirane and Naganuma also rise and follow Kurogane, carry the money-laden stands. Ikoma and Ogura are too shocked t stand. Lady Kaede is coming up the stairs. Seeing her, Ogura jum to his feet, hurriedly follows Shirane and Naganuma, as i fleeing, and descends the stairs. Ikoma, too, has no othe course than to follow them. Lady Kaede sits in front of Jiro, placing TaroвЂ™s helmet her side, and bows with both hands on the floor.
Congratulations on your victory.
Sister-in-law... you overwhelm me.  63.
I am ashamed of the wretched things I said before.
It does not matter.
I understand your father has gone mad.
I suppose you are satisfied.
Now, what night that mean?

Sister-in-law, I spoke bluntly, hiding nothing in my mind. Forgive me if I have offended you. But one would expect you to bear an intense hatred for my father, as the enemy of your family. Am I wrong?
(Looking into his eyes) Then let me talk frankly, too, Lord Jiro. I dare say you are also satisfied. JiroвЂ™s eyes return her stare.

(Looking at him, not to be stared down) Lord Jiro, you are now head of the House of Ichimonji. This helmet, too, belongs to you. She slides the helmet at her side toward Jiro. His eyes s for an instant to the helmet. At this unguarded moment, L Kaede suddenly jumps on him and pushes him down. She unsheathes his sword and bends over him, holding it to hi throat.

Lord Jiro! You have driven your father insane and murdered your brother, and stolen this realm - splendid work! But I, Kaede, will not forgive you! Foe of my husband, prepare to die!  64. Her voice is low and thick. Her expression of rage is eve more dreadful because of her beauty. Jiro is unable to mo the sword held to the base of his throat.
No...
To say that in this situation, how cowardly you are! She cuts his skin with the tip of the sword. The blood oo out.
(Deathly pale) It... was not me... who... killed my brother!
Then who was it? Jiro refuses to say.
Tell me! Who was it? She again jabs the skin at his throat. Blood oozes out.
It... was not me! Kurogane... Kurogane shot him!

Hold your tongue! You mean you ordered your retainer to do it but cannot take the responsibility? What a general! She suddenly starts laughing and raises herself off him, grabs the long sword at JiroвЂ™s side and leaps back. Jir too, jumps up, pressing his hand to his throat. Kaede, holding the dagger in one hand and the long sword in the other, is laughing. Jiro stares at her with his hand to h throat. When she finally stops laughing, she gazes at him with a faint smile.
You give in so easily. You are undependable. Now I must speak my mind straightforwardly, Lord Jiro. I could not care less about my husbandвЂ™s death.  128 65. Jiro is puzzled.

But I am worried about what is going to become of me. I do not want to live as a widow, with my hair cut, nor as a nun with my head shaved bald! This was my fatherвЂ™s castle, and I do not want to be forced to leave it! Jiro is overwhelmed by the strength in her voice and expression.

Lord Jiro. Please hear my request. I will not tell anything... your immoral acts of treason, stealing this castle and this realm... nor will my lips ever repeat the cowardly words so unworthy of a master, accusing his vassal in order to save his own life. If I told anyone, this realm would be torn apart. No, I will not... She casts aside the long sword and with the same hand gra her long dress and draws it toward her. Then she cuts it shreds with her dagger.

But remember, I could destroy it like this! What do you say, Lord Jiro? Jiro gazes at her, aghast, trembling. Lady Kaede, throwin her dagger away, jumps on him, embraces him, kisses him. stagger; his foot is caught in the hem of her long dress. They fall, their mouths together. When she pulls her lips away form his, she presses them against the wound in his throat and sucks his blood. The midsummer sun clearly illuminates the scene. From und her ruined dress her white legs are seen; a toe kicks at TaroвЂ™s helmet. The orb design on the plume catches a di ray of sunlight and gleams.
Ikoma and Ogura on horseback come side by side, depressed They stop and look up at the castle regretfully.  129 130 131 132 66.
Kurogane, Shirane, and Naganuma are watching Ikoma and Og leave. Kurogane levels his gun and fires.
Bullets hit the ground under IkomaвЂ™s and OguraвЂ™s hors rises. Ikoma and Ogura, shocked, hastily whip their horse and gallop away.
Kurogane, Shirane, and Naganuma are watching the two flee They burst into laughter.

Thrown aside are the dagger, the long sword, and TaroвЂ™s helmet on the floor. Jiro is adjusting his clothes. He co his disheveled hair with his fingers, sits down, breathin heavily, and looks out the window, turning away from Kaed Kaede is lying with her hair still undone, her clothes disordered. Summer sunlight illuminates the two of them. The clouds massed in a peak, seen in sections through the windows. Noisy voices of cicadas.
(In a soft voice) My lord... Jiro casts an exploring look at Kaede. She is silent, the back of her disheveled figure still turned to him.
What is it, sister-in-law?
How cold you are! Calling me sister- in-law after what we have just done. Jiro is silent.
Now that we have done this, I should be your wife.  67. In her expression, unseen by Jiro, is a snakelike tenacit that her voice completely belies. Jiro looks at her from behind and sighs.
But I already have SuГ© as my wife. A tiny moth flutters its wings before her downcast eyes. quietly stretches out the hand she has placed under her c and casually crushes it.
Then... am I to be... your mistress? (In tears) No, no... You are mine. I will not let anyone else have you. Jiro edges toward her and places his hand on her shoulder
Do not cry, Kaede. I would never dream of making you a mistress.
But as long as the Lady SuГ© is there...
I can take care of her.
How?
I will divorce her.
No! No! She springs up and grabs him by the chest.

The way things have turned out, I cannot forgive any woman who has known your touch. I do not want such a woman to live at the same time as I. Jiro winces. She holds him in her arms and looks directly into his eyes.  133 134 135 68.

The burned and crumbled remains of the castle. All that i left are the soaring ramparts, the ruined ramparts, a mountain of lumber burned black. In the passage, overgrow with summer grass, a single horse stands tied to a burned pillar. Beside it, where the burned lumber lies in piles, there are flagstones and stone steps going down in the ground. Smoke rises from below.

It looks as if it used to be an armory; the only trace of that past is in the construction of the walls, and the on thing left is the stone flooring. Three beds of grass hav been built alongside the wall. In the center of the stone floor is Tango; he has been placing a pot on the stone st and lighting a fire, and now he rises and goes outside.

Tango comes out from the underground storeroom and looks around. What used to be the Samurai runway is now a mere with grass. Hidetora and Kyoami are there. Tango approach the old lord, bows on his knee, tries to say something to him, but stops and is silent. Hidetora has completely changed: his eyes are sunken; his wrinkles are deepened; his disheveled white hair and bear stand on end. He is sitting in the deep grass, gazing vacantly. Kyoami, who had been leaning against the stone wall, weav grass, presents the strangely shaped hat he has woven to dispirited Hidetora.
Your helmet, my lord. Hidetora accepts it and joyfully puts it on. Tango looks it, depressed. Kyoami breaks off two lilies at his side a sticks them in HidetoraвЂ™s hat.

This is your plow-shaped plume, my lord. This is even better. Hidetora smiles joyfully under his helmet of flowers and grass. Tango suddenly rises and goes away. Then he crouch with his back to Kyoami. His shoulders are shaking furiou he seems to be crying.  136 137
(Voice-over) Am I in Hell? Tango turns around to look. Kyoami is gazing intensely in direction.

Here comes a devil! Tango follows KyoamiвЂ™s gaze. Two horsemen, Ikoma and Og are galloping near the ruined castle. When Tango recogniz them, he runs to his horse, jumps on, and races to the re of the castle ruins along the ruined passage.
